communications.phone_system_general_assessment: Telecom Cook Islands offers international direct dialing, Internet, email, fax, and Telex
communications.phone_system_international: country code - 682; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Pacific Ocean)
communications.phone_system_domestic: individual islands are connected by a combination of satellite earth stations, microwave systems, and VHF and HF radiotelephone; within the islands, service is provided by small exchanges connected to subscribers by open-wire, cable, and fiber-optic cable
communications.broadcast_media: 1 privately owned TV station broadcasts from Rarotonga providing a mix of local news and overseas-sourced programs; a satellite program package is available; 6 radio stations broadcast with 1 reportedly reaching all of the islands (2009)

economy.overview: Like many other South Pacific island nations, the Cook Islands' economic development is hindered by the isolation of the country from foreign markets, the limited size of domestic markets, lack of natural resources, periodic devastation from natural disasters, and inadequate infrastructure. Agriculture, employing more than one-quarter of the working population, provides the economic base with major exports of copra and citrus fruit. Black pearls are the Cook Islands' leading export. Manufacturing activities are limited to fruit processing, clothing, and handicrafts. Trade deficits are offset by remittances from emigrants and by foreign aid overwhelmingly from New Zealand. In the 1980s and 1990s, the country lived beyond its means, maintaining a bloated public service and accumulating a large foreign debt. Subsequent reforms, including the sale of state assets, the strengthening of economic management, the encouragement of tourism, and a debt restructuring agreement, have rekindled investment and growth.
economy.agriculture_products: copra, citrus, pineapples, tomatoes, beans, pawpaws, bananas, yams, taro, coffee; pigs, poultry
economy.industries: fruit processing, tourism, fishing, clothing, handicrafts
economy.stock_money_narrow: $38.99 million (31 December 2011 est.) ++ $38.99 million (31 December 2011 est.)
economy.stock_money_broad: $148.2 million (31 December 2011 est.) ++ $170.9 million (31 December 2010 est.)
economy.exports_commodities: copra, papayas, fresh and canned citrus fruit, coffee; fish; pearls and pearl shells; clothing
economy.imports_commodities: foodstuffs, textiles, fuels, timber, capital goods

geography.location_description: Oceania, group of islands in the South Pacific Ocean, about halfway between Hawaii and New Zealand
geography.area_note: 1.3 times the size of Washington, DC
geography.climate: tropical oceanic; moderated by trade winds; a dry season from April to November and a more humid season from December to March
geography.terrain: low coral atolls in north; volcanic, hilly islands in south
geography.notes: the northern Cook Islands are seven low-lying, sparsely populated, coral atolls; the southern Cook Islands, where most of the population lives, consist of eight elevated, fertile, volcanic isles, including the largest, Rarotonga, at 67 sq km

government.name: none
government.name_etymology: named after Captain James COOK, the British explorer who visited the islands in 1773 and 1777
government.dependency_status: self-governing in free association with New Zealand; Cook Islands is fully responsible for internal affairs; New Zealand retains responsibility for external affairs and defense in consultation with the Cook Islands
government.government_type: self-governing parliamentary democracy (Parliament of the Cook Islands) in free association with New Zealand
government.capital_time_zone: UTC-10 (5 hours behind Washington, DC, during Standard Time)
government.independence: none (became self-governing in free association with New Zealand on 4 August 1965 and has the right at any time to move to full independence by unilateral action)
government.national_holiday: Constitution Day, first Monday in August (1965)
government.constitution: 4 August 1965 (Cook Islands Constitution Act 1964); amended many times, last in 2004 (2016)
government.legal_system: common law similar to New Zealand common law
government.executive_chief_of_state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952); represented by Tom J. MARSTERS (since 9 August 2013); New Zealand High Commissioner Joanna KEMPKERS (since 19 July 2013)
government.executive_cabinet: Cabinet chosen by the prime minister
government.executive_elections: the monarchy is hereditary; UK representative appointed by the monarch; New Zealand high commissioner appointed by the New Zealand Government; following legislative elections, the leader of the majority party or majority coalition usually becomes prime minister
government.legislative_description: unicameral Parliament, formerly the Legislative Assembly (24 seats; members directly elected in single-seat constituencies by simple majority vote to serve 4-year terms); note - the House of Ariki, a 24-member parliamentary body of traditional leaders appointed by the Queen's representative serves as a consultative body to the Parliament
government.legislative_elections: last held on 9 July 2014 (next to be held by 2018)
government.legislative_election_results: percent of vote by party - NA; seats by party - CIP 13, Demo 8, One Cook Islands Movement 2, 1 undecided
government.legislative_judge_selection: High Court chief justice appointed by the Queen's Representative on the advice of the Executive Council tendered by the prime minister; other judges appointed by the Queen's Representative, on the advice of the Executive Council tendered by the chief justice, High Court chief justice, and the minister of justice; chief justice and judges appointed for 3-year renewable terms
government.political_parties: Cook Islands Party or CIP [Henry PUNA] ++ Democratic Party or Demo [William HEATHER] ++ One Cook Islands Movement [Teina BISHOP]
government.international_organization_participation: ACP, ADB, AOSIS, FAO, ICAO, ICCt, ICRM, IFAD, IFRCS, IMO, IMSO, IOC, ITUC (NGOs), OPCW, PIF, Sparteca, SPC, UNESCO, UPU, WHO, WMO
government.diplomatic_representation_in_usa: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)
government.diplomatic_representation_from_usa: none (self-governing in free association with New Zealand)
government.flag_description: blue with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and a large circle of 15 white five-pointed stars (one for every island) centered in the outer half of the flag
government.national_symbols: a circle of 15, five-pointed, white stars on a blue field; national colors: blue, white
